So, itâs less of a âthe church has replaced the Jews- go away you schmucks!â And itâs more of Jesus being like âyo, what up literally everyone in the worldâ. Also Jesus fulfilled a lot of the Old Testament, so we donât need to kill goats anymore which is cool. Does that help at all? I guess my main point is that when Jesus came, he came for the Jews AND everyone else.

Quoted, not my own work

Pizza John Shot. -Vodka (tomato flavored if you can find it) -Bloody mary mix (if you can't find tomato vodka) -1 tsp oregano -1 tsp of salt -2 tsp of black pepper -1 crushed cloves of garlic -1 tsp of sugar -A nice piece of cheesy bread (sourdough or baguette preferred) -Self adhesive fake mustache Optional -An empty Tea bag -Shredded Parmesan cheese Heat the vodka on a stove with a really really really low flame. Heat up the vodka for 5 minutes or so. It should not boil. Just get it nice and warm. Add in the herbs (in the tea bag if you have it), and turn off the flame. Let it steep for 20 minutes. While you're waiting take your shot glass and melt shredded Parmesan cheese around the rim (you don't have to do this. But I tried it, it was good) and heat up the cheesy bread. Once it is done steeping, you can chill the vodka, or just drink it warm. I can't tell which is better. Once you decide, go ahead and stick the self adhesive fake mustache to the bottom of the shot glass. Pour in 3/4 Pizza Vodka tea, 1/4 bloody mary mix. Drink it and chase it with the cheesy bread. When you lift the cup to your face, the mustache should line up just right so you look like a pizza John. Merry Pizzamas everyone!
Happy Pizzamas, Erin!

Peanut sauce
1/2 cup water
1-2+ cup creamy peanut butter (more added later to doctor recipe)
3 tbsp soy sauce (more added later to doctor recipe)
2 tbsp rice vinegar
2 tbsp sesame oil
1 tbsp vegetable oil (or canola oil)
2 tsp grated ginger root, or ginger paste
1 garlic clove, chopped (or garlic flakes)
1-2 tbsp lemon juice (or lime juice) (more added later to doctor recipe)
1 pinch of salt
I always start off with the given ingredients. The "more added later" is based off me tasting the sauce. They don't always need to be added, but most of the time that's what I end up adding
